items.name: Norwegian Geological Survey (NGU)
items.description:
Data provided by the Norwegian geological authority, NGU.

https://www.ngu.no/

items.name: BerggrunnN250
items.description:
The mapping service shows N250 bedrock data - vector.

The data is mainly based on the nationwide printed rock geological map series on a scale of 1: 250,000.
The maps are converted to digital form by scanning and vectorization.
The dataset contains only bedrock surfaces and may be locally added to new updated data. Large line structures (cracks and faults) have been established as a separate data set (rock structures).
The point symbols and measurement observations on the printed maps are not yet available in digital form.
Theme Codes and Properties segment mainly SOSI standard, version 4.0.

items.name: BerggrunnN50
items.description:
The mapping service shows N50 bedrock data - vector.

The data is mainly based on the nationwide printed rock geological map series on a scale of 1: 50,000.
The maps are scanned and digitized from printed maps. The data set includes only the bedrock surfaces.
Thematic codes and properties mainly follow the SOSI standard, version 4.0

items.name: Cores (Borkjerner WMS)
items.description:
MinresKernernWMS contains information about drill cores from the national drill core or sample center.

The drill cores are thematically divided into industrial minerals, natural stone, metal, bedrock and unspecified

items.name: BW Fish Info WMS
items.description:
The mapping service shows the distribution of sediments on the seabed, classified by grain size.

The dataset shows the best available data based on bottom sediments grain size regional (about 1: 100,000) and detailed (about 1: 20,000).
Data is updated up to 2 times per year.

items.name: Geophysics
items.description: Geophysics

items.name: Geochemistry
items.description: Geochemistry

items.name: Geological heritage
items.description:
The geological heritage mapping service shows registered geological sites that may be of interest to tourists, schoolchildren and nature managers.

We welcome proposals for corrections and new areas that should be included.

items.name: Geotreat
items.description:
Here you will find the WMS address for GeoTreat.

The application itself is an international portal for finding geological sites.
Today covers Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Finland and Australia.
The ambition is to include several countries.
With GeoTreat you can study geological points of interest via smart phone, at home or in a place in nature.

items.name: Groundwater (Granada)
items.description:
The service is related to groundwater in Norway.

Groundwater is a hidden geological resource that occurs below ground in loads and mountains.
Only under certain conditions can groundwater be observed on the surface in the form of natural occurrences such as springs or marshes.
Otherwise, knowledge of groundwater is limited to underground observations (eg in caves, mines, tunnels, etc.) or from wells.
The most important groundwater resources in Norway are in bulk.
A central systematic collection of information from groundwater wells in Norway began in 1951 when NGU established the Water Drilling Archive.
An increased need for groundwater led to increased activity in well drilling and resource mapping in the period after about 1965.
Regulations on the duty to undertake well drilling and groundwater surveys came into force on 1 January 1997 and include reporting obligations to NGU.
The national groundwater database GRANADA was opened as a mapping service on the Internet in May 2004.

items.name: Gravel and crush
items.description:
The mapping service for the gravel and crush database at NGU contains information on the vast majority of gravel and crushed deposits and extraction sites in Norway where the raw material is used for construction.

In addition, an overview of the stone tips is provided and the database itself also provides information on land use, volume, manufacturers, quality and how important the resources are as raw material for building engineering purposes.

items.name: Industrial Minerals
items.description:
The service shows registered deposits of industrial minerals divided into groups and subtypes, as well as industrial minerals - value assessment.

The service primarily serves the municipalities and Norway Digital parties.
The service is therefore developed in Norwegian.
An extended version (Prospecting.no) has been prepared for the foreign exploration companies and the professional community.

items.name: Map catalogue
items.description: Quaternary geology.

items.name: Soils
items.description:
The map insights in this mapping service are various selections of themed soil in the loose mass database at NGU.

On the largest scale, according to a professional assessment, the best quality data, either from 1:20 000, 1:50 000 or 1: 250 000, has been selected for a seamless map for the whole of Norway.
There are some analog maps that we are about to digitize and will be added to the database continuously.
See the "Map Catalog" service for analog maps.
Select "Change Map Service" from the top menu.
The map transparency loads show a simplified classification, as the theme soil according to the SOSI standard v.
4.0 consists of 78 classes.
Several map insights have been organized, which show greater detail in the classification by topic.
See the drop down menu in the upper right of the map service.

items.name: Soils, Symbols
items.description: Quaternary geology.

items.name: Marine bottom sediments and sedimentation environment
items.description:
The mapping service shows the distribution of various sediments classified by grain size and mode of formation, as well as the current sedimentation environment and processes on the seabed; Included in the mapping service are also bottom types from sea level measurement and sediment might.

Bottom reflectivity data from measurements with multi-beam echo sounder and 3D seismic provide information about the nature of the bottom (harder or softer bottom).
In addition, the mapping service shows the names of the largest banks, depths and sea areas that are often mentioned in connection with marine mapping.

items.name: Marine Geo Hazards
items.description: The mapping service shows subsea landforms related to landslide landslides as well as natural phenomena that can cause seabed instability and thus pose a threat to subsea installations and / or exposed coastal areas.

items.name: Marine basemap
items.description:
The mapping service shows a number of thematic map layers derived from detailed basic knowledge of the seabed: depth and sediments.

The following derived theme is visualized; steep slopes and flat fjord bottom (slope), anchoring conditions, digging, settling areas.
A prerequisite for drawing up marine ground maps is that detailed mapping of the seabed in the area has been carried out.

items.name: Marine landforms
items.description:
The mapping service shows a variety of landscapes on the seabed.

The interpretation is based on detailed depth data, as well as bottom reflectivity data and sediment samples.

items.name: Marine landscape
items.description:
The mapping service shows a division of the marine areas into different marine landscapes, defined as larger geographical areas with uniform visual appearance.

The classification is based on bathymetry with 50 meters resolution and is part of the basis for the nature type mapping.
The purpose of the service is to be able to visualize submarine landscapes in a way that easily communicates knowledge of Norwegian coastal and marine areas to management, industry and research.
The main focus is on disseminating the latest mapping and research results from the Mareano program, where marine landscapes are included as part of habitat mapping.

items.name: Marine habitats
items.description:
The mapping service shows the prevalence of marine biotopes, as well as shell sand deposits and glacial deposits in fjords and coastal areas.

The classification of biotopes was developed in a collaboration between the Institute of Marine Research and Norway's geological survey and is based on a number of geological and biological parameters on the seabed.
MAREANO delivers flat-coverage ecosystem and landscape-level biotopes based on visual inspection (video), environmental conditions (sampling), and interpretation of data collected with multi-ray sonar.
The prevalence of shale sand in coastal areas shows occurrences based on both mapping and modeling, and is a result of the collaboration between NGU and NIVA.
Modeled shell sand areas have been prepared under the auspices of the National Program for Mapping of Marine Biodiversity, which is managed by the Environment Directorate and the Directorate of Fisheries.
Glacial deposits in the sea represent a special type of habitat with varied animal and plant life, and have therefore been detailed and mapped by NGU in collaboration with the Environment Directorate.

items.name: Marine - Geophoto
items.description:
The purpose of this mapping service is to show examples of what different types of seabed look like with the help of localized subsea images.

Pictures have been taken as part of the documentation on most MAREANO trips since 2006, and are used as interpretations for both geologists and biologists.

items.name: Marine - Geochemistry
items.description: The mapping service presents content of heavy metals and other inorganic environmental indicators in bottom sediments.

items.name: Marine boundary and opportunity for marine clay (Quaternary geology)
items.description:
The mapping service consists of individual map layers showing Marine Border (MG) and Opportunity for Marine Camps (MML).

Marine boundary indicates the highest level that the sea reached after the last ice age.
Data for MG consists of point registrations, lines and polygons.
Lines and polygons are modeled from the points and a 10 m height model.
Shaded areas are above the MG.
The service also contains the Possible Marine Clay dataset derived from marine boundary and mass mapping, and shows where there can potentially be marine clay - either up in the day or under other types of mass.
MML is only available for areas where loads are mapped to a scale of 1:50 000 or more in detail.

There is no coverage for MML where loads are surveyed on a coarser scale, but marine deposits can still occur for areas below the marine boundary.
MML for new quarterly geological detail maps of scale 1: 10,000 is not yet included in the service.
In the MML dataset, the mapped sediment types under MG are classified according to the possibility of finding marine clay.
MML is divided into very large, large, medium, very large but incoherent / thin, small or largely absent.
MML classification does not apply to water-covered areas below the MG / in the sea, although marine clay here is common.
Landslide polygons have, for technical reasons, been pulled over the shoreline and out into the sea, and this is reflected in the MML polygons.
It is encouraged to add water polygons over MML.
Areas for possible marine clay should always be seen along with areas for marine boundary.
Read more about MG and MML including usage and uncertainties at ngu.no under disciplines / quaternary geology / marine border

items.name: Marine Seismic and Samples
items.description: The mapping service contains locations for analog seismic and digital seismic lines with images.

items.name: Metals
items.description:
The service shows registered deposits of metals.

The service is available in the application together with NatursteinWMS2, Industrial MineralsWMS2 and BergrettigheterWMS.
The service primarily serves the municipalities and Norway Digital parties.
The service is therefore developed in Norwegian.
An extended version (Prospecting.no) has been prepared for the foreign exploration companies and the professional community.

items.name: National database for basic investigations (NADAG)
items.description:
The National Database for Basic Surveys (NADAG) shows boreholes (points) where basic surveys have been carried out.

Today NADAG contains data from geotechnical drilling (geotechnical drilling) and has a viewing service for these.
The services offered by NADAG are free.
Where raw data or reports are linked up to the survey point, this can be downloaded free of charge.
There is a varying amount of information associated with each data point, depending on, among other things, the format in which the data is delivered.
No attempt has been made to correct any errors in the datasets themselves.
NADAY and contributors are not responsible for the individual use of the datasets.
When using data, reference should be made to the report / data owner.

items.name: Natural stone
items.description:
The service shows registered deposits of natural stone divided into group and subtype, as well as natural stone area - valuation.

The service primarily serves the municipalities and Norway Digital parties.
The service is therefore developed in Norwegian.
An extended version (Prospecting.no) has been prepared for the foreign exploration companies and the professional community.

items.name: Permafrost
items.description:
The service shows data organized in study areas.

A study area contains one or more measurement points, which in turn are either a borehole or a mini log where the temperature outside the boreholes is measured.
Borehole temperature data can be temperature series (monitoring) or depth temperature (logs).

items.name: Radon
items.description:
This map service shows the national radon due diligence map.

The mapping service provides an initial assessment of radon due diligence, and can be used as a tool for municipalities to assess the need for new measurements in homes and when planning new housing construction.
If an area has been classified as "high care" or "particularly high care", this should be taken into account in the municipalities' work with area plans.
Resolution of the data is no better than 1: 50,000 - that is, the data cannot be used on single plots or smaller residential areas.
The map shows the likelihood that it may or may not be a radon problem, which is why the maps are most interesting for managing follow-up mapping and developing guidelines for new housing construction.

items.name: Slide Unstable Mountain Lot
items.description:
The map service shows registered unstable mountain areas.

Various scenarios, line segments, measurement stations for motion measurements and the areas that have been systematically mapped are also shown.
The mapping service encompasses various map insights with different symbolization of the data.
to view examination status, movement speed, degree of danger and degree of risk.
Fact sheets provide useful descriptions and technical parameters for each unstable mountain range, different scenarios, and measurement stations.

items.name: Norwegian Petroleum Directorate – NPD
items.description:
Norwegian Petroleum Directorate.
The Norwegian authority on oil and gas production and exports.

https://www.npd.no/

items.name: Norwegian Watercourse and Energy directorate (NVE)
items.description:
Data provided by the Norwegian watercourse and energy authority, NVE.
NVE's thematic geodata is distributed in accordance with the Norwegian Public Data License (NLOD). NVE disclaims liability for damage caused by errors in data and incorrect use of data.

https://www.nve.no/

items.name: Norwegian Meteorological Institute (MET)

Data provided by the Norwegian Meteorological Institute, MET.
MET Norway is the meteorological service for military and civil services as well as the general public in Norway.

https://www.met.no/

items.description: Near future: based on data from precipitation radar

items.name: Bird migration paths
items.description:
Geographic centers of occurrence estimated daily for 118 migratory bird species using eBird occurrence information for the combined period 2002 to 2014. Additional details on the data and methods can be found here:
La Sorte, F.A., Fink, D., Hochachka, W.M. & Kelling, S. (2016) Convergence of broad-scale migration strategies in terrestrial birds. Proceedings of the Royal Society of London B: Biological Sciences, 283, 20152588.

_Don't forget to press the PLAY button below the map after addding this dataset._

Chlorophyll-a, reflecting wavelengths in the green part of the visible light spectrum, is the substance that helps plants capture the sun’s energy. In the water, it indicates the presence of microscopic green algae (phytoplankton). While these plants are a natural part of the reef ecosystem, elevated numbers (a bloom) of phytoplankton signal elevated nutrient levels, especially nitrogen, in the water. Typical sources are runoff from excess fertiliser being applied to crops and, to a lesser extent in the Great Barrier Reef region, sewage contamination from urban areas.
items.name: Chlorophyll-a concentration (annual)
